transcripts.text: Our next guest isn't letting anything stop her.  Amy Brooks says, no arms, no legs, no problem.  She is an author and motivational speaker.  Amy, welcome to Real Life.
Thank you so much for having me.
It's such an honor to have you here.
Thank you.
You just radiate joy and confidence.  Tell me about your story.  Let's start at the very beginning.

So, I mean, as you can see, I don't have arms or legs.  I was born this way.  In the medical world, it's called tetraphocomelia, and so that basically just means I was born without arms and legs.  I was left abandoned at the hospital by my birth family and soon adopted by a loving Christian family, the Brookses.  And they didn't treat me as though I was handicapped.  So I grew up with my other four siblings the way that, like any other child.
Did you ever fight?

Oh, sure.  But, you know, to be honest, you know, I was closer in age to my nieces and nephews, so those were the ones that I played with.  But, I mean, yeah, we fought.  I mean, they knew they could knock me over easy, so that's what they did to me.  And I have a little bone in my short arm that I would dig into them if they, you know.  That was my way of getting back, but, you know.  So, but, yeah, I mean, sibling, sibling fun, you know.  Yeah, yeah, yeah.

Well, you know, one of the things that you had mentioned, we had talked before about the word disability.  And you have a different word, which I love the perspective that you have.  Share that with us.
I would just say that I'm differently abled.  I can do almost everything that anybody else can do.  I just have to find a different way of doing them.

Okay, yeah, because you do some pretty phenomenal things here.  Like, we have a table full of what Amy does here.  She makes purses.  Like, I don't even know anybody that makes purses.  Getting a pattern, cutting it out.  Tell me that process.

So, basically, anything that I do, I do with my mouth or my little arms.  And so, yeah, I cut out the fabric and everything with a rotary cutter in my mouth.  And... The patterns I have to cut out with an X-Acto knife because I can't really use scissors.  And I use a sewing machine that I just love.  I can thread the machine myself, but it has an automatic needle threader and I don't have to press the foot pedal because it just has a start and stop button.  I feed the fabric through with my little arm, or I hold a chopstick in my mouth that a friend of mine put some gaff tape on and some Plasti Dip to give it a little grip, and I use that to feed the fabric through the machine.  Wow.
Well, I heard that you had some grip somewhere else at one point with some glue and some issues at one point when you first started off.

Yeah, so that didn't really have to do with sewing, but when I was young, I've always been crafty and artsy, and I love to create things, and I wanted to do something with a hot glue gun, and my mom was like, you are absolutely not using
a hot

glue gun.  And so, but, you know, when she says, you can't do that, I'm always quick to prove you wrong and, you know, show you that I can.  So I took the hot glue gun and I had to sneak it so that she wouldn't see.  Oh, my goodness.  But, so I was gluing away, but if you've ever used a hot glue gun, you know those tiny little hair-like strings of glue that get in the way?  Yes, they're terrible.  And I went to pull one out of the way with my lips and I missed.  And I hit the, both top and bottom lip hit the metal nozzle.  Oh.  And I got a pretty nasty burn, but I did it.  And my mom's a little bit more careful now about what she tells me I can and can't do.

Yeah, because you hot glued your lips together.  Yes, that's kind of a big deal.  But I kind of love that about you.  There's a deep, strong will in you that if somebody says, oh, you can't do this, you say... And then you don't really say, I can't.  You say, watch me do it.

I mean, either I'm stupid or God has just given me the will to, you know, I mean, I'm fearless in that way.  I mean, I have fear about other things, but about trying new things.  I love to try new things.  I'm not worried, you know, scared about taking something new on or a challenge to me.  To me, it's an adventure to try something new and challenging.

I love it.  Well, I think it's amazing if you look at all the stuff here that's on the table because you do all of this from scratch.  It isn't like you're just taking a little bit on there.  I want to make sure people understand that at home that she's not just taking a couple of things here and putting them together.  These are beautiful.  These are beautiful things.  The picture here.
Yeah, yeah.
This is like... That's amazing.

This is amazing because... Tell me the process of how you did this.  It's like 3D.  I'm not sure if you can see it in the camera.  It's like 3D and it's layered and it's cut out.  Tell us how you cut it out, how you got the idea.  And it's so detailed to think that you did this with your mouth.

I just, it's amazing.  It's a technique called paper toll and it's been around for a really long time.  And I actually had seen something similar at just like a craft show and I thought it was amazing and I wanted to try it myself.  so I decided to have my mom buy a piece so that I could get it home and tear it apart and see how it was made.  Basically what I do is there are about five to six copies of the same photo and I take an X-Acto knife in my mouth and I cut out all of the intricate little pieces and then you use one as a base layer and you take silicone to create that depth and you place all those little pieces on top of each other.  You were talking about 3D, but it's kind of more than 3D because there's way more than three layers in there.  Right, right.  Wow.
How long does it take to do something like this?

So the picture probably took me about a week or so.  Wow.  I mean, that's not my drawing or anything.  a couple of photos of something from Norman Rockwell.  But the big person in front of you with Snoopy.  Snoopy, your favorite.  That was the latest one that I've done and I did it for my sister because she loves Snoopy too.  That took me three weeks.  It's the hardest one I've done so far.  It's beautiful.  It's made out of cork and so it's a little bit harder to work with and you can't really make mistakes because you can't take your stitches out.  You'll see holes in it.  So that was really That one was challenging for me, but she loves it, so I'm happy.
So Amy, you're an author.  You've written not one, but two books.  You are sewing, you are doing art, you're creating.  What are some of your other goals and dreams and visions?

I would love to learn how to drive.  Drive?  Okay, yeah.  I took a little evaluation and they put me on the road and I was able to do it.  So that's something that I would love to do in the future if I'm able to.  In fact, Caring Hearts, who you'll be talking to later, I believe, has started a GoFundMe campaign in my honor to help raise a, funds for a van, so that's really been amazing of them to have them come alongside me in that way.
You also said that people can get your product by a donation, is that correct?
Yeah, a suggested donation towards my trust fund and that will help me in the future to stay independent financially when I don't have my parents to help me.
Amy, how important is a good sense of humor in life?

I mean, we were talking about perspective, and I think that laughter is the best medicine.  And if you're not going to laugh about something, you're going to cry, and it's much funner to laugh, I think.  But, I mean, that's something that my parents instilled in me.  We are a crazy family, and I love to laugh.  I mean, we have tons of hilarious stories.
Tell me a little bit about how your faith has played a role in your life.  How has Jesus Christ been an impact?

That's also something that my family instilled in me that God doesn't make mistakes and that we're all here for a purpose.  And so my faith has really gotten me through those tough times.  And he's brought so many people into my life along the way to help me with those challenges.  And so, yeah.
What does your prayer life and your Bible study life look like?

Not as good as it should be.  I mean, we all hope we can all improve in that area, I believe.  But I definitely, you know, he's the one that I go to for everything, and the one that I praise for everything that he's given me.  And, you know, like we were talking about perspective, My mom has always taught me that there's always somebody else going through something that's, you know, worse than what you're going through.  And it's good to keep that in perspective and to be thankful for what God has given me and the talents he has given me.  And so I try to keep that in mind.
I think it's really amazing.  I mean, unseen arms, you've got the purses, the pictures, and all those things, but you're also a YouTube celebrity.  How she does it, am I correct?  Is that how?
How does she do it?  How does she do it?

Tell us a little bit about that.  I did see a little bit of when you were typing, which was amazing.  If you haven't seen that, you've got to go to the YouTube page.  And you can go to ctvn.org and find out more information about it.  But it's amazing to see what you do so quickly with that.  So tell us a little bit about how you type and how you use your phone.
How do you use your phone?

Well, like I said, I do pretty much everything with my mouth.  I text with my lips, and if I want to respond really fast, I use my tongue.  But yeah, the channel, I wouldn't say I'm a celebrity, but it was just mainly a place where I could share the things that God has allowed me to be able to do, the independence that He allows me to have, and to be able to share that with others who might feel like they can't do something or aren't capable of it or don't have the talent to do something.  And I just hope that it's encouraging people to people who think that they can't, to show them that they can.

So what if somebody's watching today and they're really discouraged and they really feel like, I don't really see the hope.  I don't see the hope in this.  I don't see a light at the end of the tunnel.  How would you encourage them today?

I would just say that God doesn't make mistakes and that we're all here for a reason and He doesn't call us to something that he is not going to be right there by our side to get to get us through and that you have the strength you have.  you have the power that you know that God that God gives you when you're a child of his and you're not doing it on your own strength.  so Philippians 4 13 says I can do all things through Christ who strengthens me.  and So, yeah, I mean, my life scripture is I'm fearfully and wonderfully made.  Your works are wonderful.  I know that full well because he doesn't make mistakes.  And so he knows everything about you already and the things that you need.

There's one other thing I wanted to mention, though.  I love the kind of the byline of all your product.  They couldn't see it.  I don't know if we can.  I grab that.  Is that all right if I grab it on here?  There is a real unique lips on there.  What is the byline of all your product?
Yeah, so my logo that I stitch into all of my sewing products is stitched with a kiss.  And since I use my mouth, yeah.

Because you were stitched with a kiss, the kiss of God.  And you have blessed us and you've blessed so many.  And you're going to continue to inspire and encourage so many with your faith and your life.  Thank you so much for coming, Amy.  It's such an honor to have you here.  And you too.  We're stitched with a kiss.  The very kiss, the very fingerprint of God is on your life.  And he does not make mistakes.  And you're fearfully and wonderfully made.  He loves you like crazy.
